Did you know? When you pick up meals, you are also providing financial support to our food service department. Because of you, we are able to continue feeding students, purchasing food, and avoiding additional layoffs.

Each child is entitled to one breakfast and lunch at one of our five locations.

Please visit www.agasd.org for more information or contact our Food Service Director, Troy Golden at 724-564-7190 ext. 8123.

The lunch for Thursday May 14th will be placed in the meal bag you receive today May 13th. Lunch for May 14th is an individual serving of frozen Mac & Cheese.

Please follow the heating instructions below:

Microwave Heating Instructions (from thawed):

If frozen, thaw pouches of pasta in the refrigerator for 24 hours. Cut 1/2” slit in bag and place slit side up in microwave. Heat on high power for 60 seconds.

Allow bag to cool, carefully remove from microwave, pour into a bowl and serve.

Stove Top Heating Instructions (from thawed):

Empty thawed pasta into an 8-inch sauté pan or small pot. Heat over medium/low heat for 2-3 minutes or until product reaches desired temperature. Remove from heat, stir and serve.

Student Chromebook Repair Procedures

Below are instructions on how we will be handling student Chromebook repairs beginning on April 7th. For the safety of parents/students, as well as our IT staff – these guidelines MUST be strictly followed.

Every Tuesday between 9:00am and 11:00am, you can drop your Chromebook off at the main entrance of the High School (1119 Township Drive). You will NOT need to get out of your car. Every Thursday between 9:00am and 11:00am, you can pick up your repaired/replaced Chromebook at the SAME location (HS main entrance). Again, you will NOT need to get out of your car.

For any questions or concerns, please email Chris Bolin, Director of Technology at cbolin@agasd.org

Thank you for your cooperation,

Chris

To the Albert Gallatin School District Community:

On Thursday after the end of the school day, a threat was made on social media specifically mentioning “South Middle School”. Fortunately, a concerned parent contacted administration informing us of this threat. Upon receiving the information, administration immediately contacted the Pennsylvania State Police and district administrators. In a collaborative effort with the PSP, Morgantown Police, and another school system, it was determined the threat was neither posted by a student in the Albert Gallatin School District nor was it directed toward one of our schools.

As you know the Albert Gallatin School District prioritizes the safety of all of its students and staff. We are fortunate to have parents, students and community members who exercise diligence in reporting information as soon as they become aware of it. Your efforts help us immensely in protecting our children and staff.

Please be advised that all district schools will be operating on a normal schedule tomorrow (Friday, May 24th).
